newsitem.title: RUSSIA: AGROKHLEB - Russia 96 sugarbeet crop put at 18 mln T.
newsitem.headline: AGROKHLEB - Russia 96 sugarbeet crop put at 18 mln T.

text.p: The following is a direct contribution from the Agrokhleb Report, published by SovEcon Ltd, an independent research organisation specialising in agricultural production and trade in the former Soviet Union.
SOVECON SEES RUSSIA'S 1996 SUGARBEET OUTPUT AT ABOUT 18 MILLION TONNES, 5 PCT DOWN ON 1995 LEVELS
MOSCOW, Aug 22 - Russia's area sown to sugarbeets declined in 1996 to 1,071 thousand hectares, slightly down on last year, and the fourth year in a row of planting area decline.
This trend indicates relatively poor returns from sugarbeet farming.
But it also reflects a rise in raw sugar imports which are highly competitive with domestic sugarbeet production.
In 1996, weather conditions in the major beet-growing areas -- the Central Chernozem (the Central Black Earth) and the North Caucasus regions -- were generally favourable.
But yields are forecast at low levels due to sharply decreased rates of fertiliser application, which was 140 kg per hectare this crop year, down from 431 kg per hectare in 1990.
Assuming normal crop development in August, Russia's average sugarbeet yields are expected at about 17 tonnes per hectare, below year-ago levels.
This year's crop will be close to the 1991-1995 average of 17 tonnes per hectare but significantly lower than crops of the late 1980s, when yields were 22.5 tonnes per hectare.

As a result, SovEcon forecasts the 1996 sugarbeet crop at 17-19 million tonnes, about five percent below the 1995 crop and the second lowest output in the last 40 years, after the 1993 crop (Table 2).
All forecasts at this stage remain quite tentative.
The crop depends crucially on weather conditions until the beginning of large-scale harvesting and on machinery mobilised for the harvest.
TABLE 1. RUSSIA - SUGARBEET PLANTINGS BY REGIONS: 1992-1996
TABLE 2. RUSSIA - SUGARBEET OUTPUT BY REGIONS: 1992-1996
